title: Effects of a Combined TMS and Cognitive Training in Alzheimer Patients: A Single-Center, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study
description_brief: This study looks at the potential benefits of combining cognitive training (mental exercises) together with transcranial magnetic stimulation (also known as TMS) to see if this can make a difference in the condition of people with Alzheimer's disease by improving their disease and the cognitive decline that goes along with it.
description_detailed:
This study takes place in Boston, Massachusetts and Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center. The treatment portion of the study requires patients to visit the BIDMC daily, Monday through Friday, for 6 weeks. All participants will receive real cognitive training, but half of our participants will receive active TMS treatment and half will receive a placebo TMS treatment. However, those receiving the placebo treatment will be offered the real treatment upon the completion of the study. This study goes up to approximately 4.5 months.

TMS is a noninvasive way of stimulating the brain, which is not painful and does not involve any needles or any form of surgery. It acts by delivering a magnetic stimulation to a particular region of your brain and that, coupled with the cognitive training, is what is being looked at in this study. The investigators are examining if this combination of TMS and cognitive training will improve your memory function and other mental functions such as language, orientation, and thinking or judgment.

groups.title: Active rTMS With Real Cognitive Training
groups.description:
High frequency rTMS stimulation to the left and right parietal cortex (somatosensory association cortex), left and right DLPFC (dorsolateral prefrontal cortex), and left superior temporal gyrus (Broca's area).

Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS): Each subject will receive up to 1800 pulses of up to 20Hz per day to all simulated brain regions together. Treated brain areas will be alternated each day (only 3 a day).

Sham participants will receive the same study procedures as patients receiving active rTMS.

NICE Cognitive Training: 12 levels of difficulty in tasks designed to relate to the region of the brain being stimulated (left and right parietal cortex, left and right DLPFC, left superior temporal gyrus, left inferior frontal gyrus).

A particular cognitive exercise will start 200msec after the termination of each TMS train.

Sham participants receive real cognitive training that follows the same procedures as the active group.

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: Total number analyzed: 21 (1 enrolled was excluded from analysis) Real/Real: 10 Real/Sham: 5 Sham/Sham: 6

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog)
outcomeMeasures.description: Assessment to measure the severity of all of the most important symptoms of Alzheimer's disease: loss of memory, language, praxis, and attention. The total scoring range is 0-70, with 0 representing the least impairment and 70 the most severe impairment. The results posted below represent a change in score from baseline. A positive change represents an improvement on the ADAS-Cog (change = 1 month score - baseline score).

outcomeMeasures.title: Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC)
outcomeMeasures.description: The CGI is a three-item scale used to assess treatment response in psychiatric patients. The CGI-C subset measures the global improvement or change from baseline. Scores range from 0 to 7, with 0 indicating marked improvement and 7 indicating marked worsening. The scores below represent the percent change of the scores from baseline.

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study - Activities of Daily Living Inventory (ADCS-ADL)
outcomeMeasures.description: 23 item scale to assess activities of daily living. Scores range from 0 to 78 with a higher score indicating less functional impairment. The scores reported below are the means of the actual scores from the assessments representing the percent change from baseline.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse events were collected from baseline to 1 month post-treatment
adverseEventsModule.description: All adverse events were self-reported according to a Side Effects Questionnaire administered at each visit.

seriousEvents.notes: A subject sustained a 5cm contusion and subtle rib fracture resulting from a fall at home. Subject was brought to the hospital for evaluation. Subject was in the follow up phase. This was assessed as unlikely related to to the study.

otherEvents.notes: Subject experienced twitching in bicep and wrist flexor of the right arm at the beginning of a TMS session that lasted for 5 seconds and resolved. Subject also reported nausea and session was discontinued.
Reported headaches ranged from mild to moderate post-intervention as compared to pre-intervention. Most were assessed as possibly/probably related to the study.
Reported mild hearing impairment post-intervention as compared to pre-intervention. Earplugs were worn throughout every session. No long term hearing impairment reported.
Reported mild impaired cognition post-intervention compared to pre-intervention. Most reported as tiredness. No long term impairment reported.
Reported mild trouble concentrating post-intervention as compared to pre-intervention. Most reported as tiredness. No long term trouble reported.
Reported mild tiredness post-intervention as compared to pre-intervention.
Participant reported mild soreness at the inferior frontal gyrus (stimulation site) post-stimulation.
Blurry vision reported after looking at computer screen for extended period of time
Reported mild dizziness post-intervention as compared to pre-intervention.
Participant reported feeling mildly subdued/dazed/depressed following intervention. No long term effects.
Reported mild eye heaviness post-intervention. No long term effects.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention described is non-pharmacologic — transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) combined with cognitive training — aimed at improving cognitive function and slowing cognitive decline in people with Alzheimer’s disease. This matches the intent of a cognitive-enhancing intervention rather than a biologic or small-molecule drug targeting Alzheimer pathology (e.g., amyloid or tau).

Act: I searched the literature for trials of combined TMS and cognitive training in AD and found multiple randomized, double-blind, sham-controlled studies and reviews showing this exact intervention (rTMS or TMS paired with cognitive training) is assessed as a means to improve cognition in AD (examples: Rabey et al. randomized study and related trials and reviews). citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search7turn0search2

Reflect: Classification check — the trial does not involve a monoclonal antibody, vaccine, or other biologic (so not 'disease-targeted biologic'), nor a small-molecule drug (so not 'disease-targeted small molecule'), nor is it focused primarily on behavioral/psychiatric symptoms (so not 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement'). Its primary target is cognitive improvement via non-drug brain stimulation plus training, so 'cognitive enhancer' is the correct category. The protocol is typically placebo-controlled with sham TMS as the control. citeturn0search1turn0search3
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is non-pharmacologic — transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) combined with cognitive training — intended to improve cognitive function by enhancing neuroplasticity and synaptic function rather than by acting on amyloid, tau, inflammation, or other molecular AD pathologies. Clinical and review literature describe rTMS effects on synaptic plasticity and LTP-like cortical changes underlying cognitive improvements. citeturn0search6turn0search4

Act: Extracted details from the trial description: title indicates combined TMS + cognitive training; trial category listed as 'cognitive enhancer'; no drug or molecular target listed. Multiple randomized, double-blind, sham-controlled trials and a multicenter neuroAD™ study specifically testing neuronavigated rTMS combined with cognitive training report symptomatic cognitive benefits, supporting a mechanism of enhanced neuroplasticity rather than a disease-specific molecular target. citeturn0search2turn0search9turn0search0

Reflect: Classification check — this intervention is not a monoclonal antibody, vaccine, small molecule, or diagnostic, and it specifically aims to improve cognition via neuromodulation and plasticity. Therefore the best CADRO fit is M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection. The evidence base (randomized trials, multicenter study, reviews, and meta-analyses) supports this assignment. citeturn0search8turn0search6
Evidence (selected web search results cited above):
- Rabey et al., randomized double-blind rTMS + cognitive training study showing ADAS-cog improvement. citeturn0search2
- neuroAD™ multicenter randomized, sham-controlled trial (neuronavigated rTMS + cognitive training) reporting benefit in milder AD. citeturn0search9
- Review summarizing rTMS mechanisms in AD including enhanced synaptic plasticity, neurotrophic effects, and neurotransmitter modulation. citeturn0search6
- Study linking cortical LTP-like plasticity to cognitive improvement after rTMS in AD. citeturn0search4
- Systematic review/meta-analysis showing high-frequency rTMS (especially DLPFC-targeted) can improve global cognition in age-related neurodegenerative diseases. citeturn0search8
